member.name: T:CoreTweet.OAuth
member.summary: Provides a set of static (Shared in Visual Basic) methods for OAuth authentication.

member.name: M:CoreTweet.OAuth.AuthorizeAsync(System.String,System.String,System.String,CoreTweet.ConnectionOptions,System.Threading.CancellationToken)

summary.para: Generates the authorize URI as an asynchronous operation.
Then call after get the pin code.

param.name: oauthCallback
param.para: For OAuth 1.0a compliance this parameter is required.
The value you specify here will be used as the URL a user is redirected to should they approve your application's access to their account.
Set this to oob for out-of-band pin mode.
This is also how you specify custom callbacks for use in desktop/mobile applications.
Always send an oauth_callback on this step, regardless of a pre-registered callback.

member.param: The connection options for the request.

returns.para: The task object representing the asynchronous operation.
The Result property on the task object returns the authorize URI.

summary.para: Gets the OAuth tokens as an asynchronous operation.
Be sure to call before call this method.

returns.para: The task object representing the asynchronous operation.
The Result property on the task object returns the tokens.

summary.para: Gets or sets an array of integers indicating the offsets within the Tweet text where the URL begins and ends.
The first integer represents the location of the first character of the URL in the Tweet text.
The second integer represents the location of the first non-URL character occurring after the URL (or the end of the string if the URL is the last part of the Tweet text).

summary.para: Represents a place, which are specific, named locations with corresponding geo coordinates.

summary.para: Gets or sets a series of longitude and latitude points, defining a box which will contain the Place entity this bounding box is related to.

summary.para: Represents the Tweets, which are the basic atomic building block of all things Twitter.
Users tweet Tweets, also known more generically as "status updates."
Tweets can be embedded, replied to, favorited, unfavorited and deleted.
Gets or sets the integer representation of the unique identifier for this Tweet.
Gets or sets the collection of brief user objects (usually only one) indicating users who contributed to the authorship of the tweet, on behalf of the official tweet author.
Gets or sets the value represents the geographic location of the Tweet as reported by the user or client application.

member.name: P:CoreTweet.Status.CreatedAt
member.summary: Gets or sets the time when the Tweet was created.

summary.para: Gets or sets the Tweet ID of the user's own retweet of this Tweet, if exists.
Only surfaces on methods supporting the include_my_retweet parameter, when set to true.

member.name: P:CoreTweet.Status.Entities
member.summary: Gets or sets the entities which have been parsed out of the text of the Tweet.

member.name: P:CoreTweet.Status.ExtendedEntities
member.summary: Gets or sets the extended entities which may have multiple entities data.

summary.para: Gets or sets a number of approximately how many times the Tweet has been favorited by Twitter users.
Gets or sets a value that determines if the Tweet has been favorited by the authenticating user.
Gets or sets the screen name of the original Tweet's author if the represented Tweet is a reply.
Gets or sets the integer representation of the original Tweet's ID if the represented Tweet is a reply.
Gets or sets the integer representation of the original Tweet's author ID if the represented Tweet is a reply.
Gets or sets the place that the tweet is associated.
Gets or sets a value that determines if the URL contained in the tweet may contain content or media identified as sensitive content.
This field only surfaces when a tweet contains a link and the meaning of the filed doesn't pertain to the Tweet content itself.
Gets or sets a set of key-value pairs indicatse the intended contextual delivery of the containing Tweet.
Currently used by Twitter's Promoted Products.
Gets or sets a number of approximately how many times the Tweet has been retweeted by Twitter users.
Gets or sets a value that determines if the Tweet has been retweeted by the authenticating user.
Gets or sets the original Tweet if the status is a retweet.
Users can amplify the broadcast of tweets authored by other users by retweeting.
Retweets can be distinguished from typical Tweets by the existence of a retweeted_status attribute.
This attribute contains a representation of the original Tweet that was retweeted.
Note that retweets of retweets do not show representations of the intermediary retweet, but only the original tweet.
(Users can also unretweet a retweet they created by deleting their retweet.)
Gets or sets the utility used to post the Tweet, as an HTML-formatted string.
A tweet from the Twitter website has a value of "web" (case-insensitive).
Gets or sets the actual text of the status update.
Gets or sets a value that determines if the value of the text parameter was truncated, for example, as a result of a retweet exceeding the 140 character Tweet length.
Truncated text will end in ellipsis, like this ...
Gets or sets the user who posted the Tweet.
Perspectival attributes embedded within this object are unreliable.
Gets or sets a value that determines if this piece of content has been withheld due to a DMCA complaint.
Gets or sets a list of uppercase two-letter country codes this content is withheld from.
Gets or sets the content being withheld is the "status" or a "user."
Represents the Tweet with rate limit.
Tweets are the basic atomic building block of all things Twitter.
Users tweet Tweets, also known more generically as "status updates."
Tweets can be embedded, replied to, favorited, unfavorited and deleted.

member.name: M:CoreTweet.Rest.Account.UpdateProfileBannerAsync(System.Linq.Expressions.Expression{System.Func{System.String,System.Object}}[])

summary.para: Uploads a profile banner on behalf of the authenticating user as an asynchronous operation.
For best results, upload an <3MB image that is exactly 1500px by 500px.
Images will be resized for a number of display options. Users with an uploaded profile banner will have a profile_banner_url node in their Users objects.
More information about sizing variations can be found in https://dev.twitter.com/docs/user-profile-images-and-banners.
Profile banner images are processed asynchronously.
The profile_banner_url and its variant sizes will not necessary be available directly after upload.

member.returns: The task object representing the asynchronous operation.

summary.para: Updates the authenticating user's profile image as an asynchronous operation.
Note that this method expects raw multipart data, not a URL to an image.
This method asynchronously processes the uploaded file before updating the user's profile image URL.
You can either update your local cache the next time you request the user's information, or, at least 5 seconds after uploading the image, ask for the updated URL using GET users/show.

returns.para: The task object representing the asynchronous operation.
The Result property on the task object returns the user object.

summary.para: Blocks the specified user from following the authenticating user as an asynchronous operation.

If a follow or friend relationship exists it is destroyed.

member.name: T:CoreTweet.Rest.DirectMessages
member.summary: Provides a set of methods for the wrapper of GET/POST direct_messages.

summary.para: Returns the 20 most recent direct messages sent to the authenticating user as an asynchronous operation.
Includes detailed information about the sender and recipient user.
You can request up to 200 direct messages per call, up to a maximum of 800 incoming DMs.
This method requires an access token with RWD (read, write and direct message) permissions.

returns.para: The task object representing the asynchronous operation.
The Result property on the task object returns the direct messages.

member.name: T:CoreTweet.Rest.Followers
member.summary: Provides a set of methods for the wrapper of GET followers.

summary.para: Returns a cursored collection of user IDs for every user following the specified user as an asynchronous operation.
At this time, results are ordered with the most recent following first; however this ordering is subject to unannounced change and eventual consistency issues.
Results are given in groups of 5,000 user IDs and multiple "pages" of results can be navigated through using the next_cursor value in subsequent requests.
This method is especially powerful when used in conjunction with GET users/lookup, a method that allows you to convert user IDs into full user objects in bulk.

returns.para: The task object representing the asynchronous operation.
The Result property on the task object returns the IDs.

summary.para: Locates places near the given coordinates which are similar in name as an asynchronous operation.
Conceptually you would use this method to get a list of known places to choose from first.
Then, if the desired place doesn't exist, make a request to POST geo/place to create a new one.
The token contained in the response is the token needed to be able to create a new place.

returns.para: The task object representing the asynchronous operation.
The Result property on the task object returns the places and the token.

summary.para: Search for places that can be attached to a statuses/update as an asynchronous operation.
Given a latitude and a longitude pair, an IP address, or a name, this request will return a list of all the valid places that can be used as the place_id when updating a status.

Conceptually, a query can be made from the user's location, retrieve a list of places, have the user validate the location he or she is at, and then send the ID of this location with a call to POST statuses/update.
This is the recommended method to use find places that can be attached to statuses/update.
Unlike GET geo/reverse_geocode which provides raw data access, this endpoint can potentially re-order places with regards to the user who is authenticated.
This approach is also preferred for interactive place matching with the user.
Note: At least one of the following parameters must be provided to this resource: lat, long, ip, or query

returns.para: The task object representing the asynchronous operation.
The Result property on the task object returns the places.

summary.para: Adds multiple members to a list, by specifying a comma-separated list of member ids or screen names as an asynchronous operation.
The authenticated user must own the list to be able to add members to it.
Note that lists can't have more than 500 members, and you are limited to adding up to 100 members to a list at a time with this method.
Please note that there can be issues with lists that rapidly remove and add memberships.
Take care when using these methods such that you are not too rapidly switching between removals and adds on the same list.

member.name: T:CoreTweet.Rest.Search

summary.para: Returns a collection of relevant Tweets matching a specified query as an asynchronous operation.
Please note that Twitter's search service and, by extension, the Search API is not meant to be an exhaustive source of Tweets.
Not all Tweets will be indexed or made available via the search interface.

returns.para: The task object representing the asynchronous operation.
The Result property on the task object returns the statuses.

summary.para: Returns the 20 most recent mentions (tweets containing a users's @screen_name) for the authenticating user as an asynchronous operation.
The timeline returned is the equivalent of the one seen when you view your mentions on twitter.com.
This method can only return up to 800 tweets.

returns.para: The task object representing the asynchronous operation.
The Result property on the task object returns the statuses.

summary.para: Returns a collection of the most recent Tweets posted by the user indicated by the screen_name or user_id parameters as an asynchronous operation.
User timelines belonging to protected users may only be requested when the authenticated user either "owns" the timeline or is an approved follower of the owner.
The timeline returned is the equivalent of the one seen when you view a user's profile on twitter.com.
This method can only return up to 3,200 of a user's most recent Tweets.
Native retweets of other statuses by the user is included in this total, regardless of whether include_rts is set to false when requesting this resource.

returns.para: The task object representing the asynchronous operation.
The Result property on the task object returns the statuses.

summary.para: Returns a collection of the most recent Tweets and retweets posted by the authenticating user and the users they follow as an asynchronous operation.
The home timeline is central to how most users interact with the Twitter service.
Up to 800 Tweets are obtainable on the home timeline.
It is more volatile for users that follow many users or follow users who tweet frequently.

returns.para: The task object representing the asynchronous operation.
The Result property on the task object returns the statuses.

summary.para: Returns information allowing the creation of an embedded representation of a Tweet on third party sitesas an asynchronous operation.

While this endpoint allows a bit of customization for the final appearance of the embedded Tweet, be aware that the appearance of the rendered Tweet may change over time to be consistent with Twitter's Display Requirements.
Do not rely on any class or id parameters to stay constant in the returned markup.

returns.para: The task object representing the asynchronous operation.
The Result property on the task object returns the HTML code and more.

While this endpoint allows a bit of customization for the final appearance of the embedded Tweet, be aware that the appearance of the rendered Tweet may change over time to be consistent with Twitter's Display Requirements.
Do not rely on any class or id parameters to stay constant in the returned markup.

returns.para: The task object representing the asynchronous operation.
The Result property on the task object returns the HTML code and more.

summary.para: Updates the authenticating user's current status, also known as tweeting as an asynchronous operation.
To upload an image to accompany the tweet, use POST statuses/update_with_media.
For each parameters attempt, the parameters text is compared with the authenticating user's recent tweets.
Any attempt that would result in duplication will be blocked, resulting in a 403 error.
Therefore, a user cannot submit the same status twice in a row.
While not rate limited by the API a user is limited in the number of tweets they can create at a time.
If the number of updates posted by the user reaches the current allowed limit this method will return an HTTP 403 error.

returns.para: The task object representing the asynchronous operation.
The Result property on the task object returns the updated status.

Returns a collection of the most recent Tweets posted by the user indicated by the screen_name or user_id parameters.
User timelines belonging to protected users may only be requested when the authenticated user either "owns" the timeline or is an approved follower of the owner.

Native retweets of other statuses by the user is included in this total, regardless of whether include_rts is set to false when requesting this resource.

summary.para: Returns the locations that Twitter has trending topic information for as an asynchronous operation.
The response is an array of "locations" that encode the location's id and some other human-readable information such as a canonical name and country the location belongs in.
A id is a Yahoo! Where On Earth ID.

returns.para: The task object representing the asynchronous operation.
The Result property on the task object returns the locations.

summary.para: Returns the top 10 trending topics for a specific id, if trending information is available for it as an asynchronous operation.
The response is an array of "trend" objects that encode the name of the trending topic, the query parameter that can be used to search for the topic on Twitter Search, and the Twitter Search URL.
This information is cached for 5 minutes.
Requesting more frequently than that will not return any more data, and will count against your rate limit usage.

member.name: T:CoreTweet.Streaming.DisconnectCode
member.summary: Provides disconnect codes in Twitter Streaming API.

member.name: F:CoreTweet.Streaming.DisconnectCode.Shutdown
member.summary: The feed was shutdown (possibly a machine restart)

member.name: F:CoreTweet.Streaming.DisconnectCode.DuplicateStream
member.summary: The same endpoint was connected too many times.

member.name: F:CoreTweet.Streaming.DisconnectCode.ControlRequest
member.summary: Control streams was used to close a stream (applies to sitestreams).

member.name: F:CoreTweet.Streaming.DisconnectCode.Stall
member.summary: The client was reading too slowly and was disconnected by the server.

member.name: F:CoreTweet.Streaming.DisconnectCode.Normal
member.summary: The client appeared to have initiated a disconnect.

member.name: F:CoreTweet.Streaming.DisconnectCode.TokenRevoked
member.summary: An oauth token was revoked for a user (applies to site and userstreams).

member.name: F:CoreTweet.Streaming.DisconnectCode.AdminLogout
member.summary: The same credentials were used to connect a new stream and the oldest was disconnected.

summary.para: Will not be delivered to external clients.

member.name: F:CoreTweet.Streaming.DisconnectCode.MaxMessageLimit
member.summary: The stream connected with a negative count parameter and was disconnected after all backfill was delivered.

member.name: F:CoreTweet.Streaming.DisconnectCode.StreamException
member.summary: An internal issue disconnected the stream.

member.name: F:CoreTweet.Streaming.DisconnectCode.BrokerStall
member.summary: An internal issue disconnected the stream.

summary.para: The host the stream was connected to became overloaded and streams were disconnected to balance load.
